sections.summary: These verses emphasize the **tremendous quaking** of the Hour and describe the vulnerability of all creation on that Day. It presents the stages of human **creation** from dust and fluid as definitive proof for those who doubt the **Resurrection**.

The text rebukes those who argue about Allah without **knowledge** or an **enlightening scripture** and exposes the "edge-worshiper" who turns away during an **ordeal** [440–441]. It affirms that those who do righteous deeds will be admitted into **Gardens** through divine **guidance**.

Allah establishes His role as the ultimate **Judge** over diverse religious communities on the Day of Resurrection. The entire universe, including the sun, moon, and stars, is described in a state of **prostration**, contrasting the punishment of **Fire** for the defiant with the **gold and pearls** awarded to the faithful [441–442].

sections.theme: Abraham and the Rites of Hajj
sections.summary: This section details the commissioning of **Abraham** to purify the House and announce the **Pilgrimage (Hajj)** to all humanity. It establishes the **sanctity** of the rites and clarifies that the purpose of animal offerings is the commemoration of Allah's Name and the **piety** of the heart rather than the flesh or blood [442–443].

Permission is granted to those who are fought against to defend themselves because they were **wronged** and unjustly evicted. Allah is identified as the protector of all **places of worship**—monasteries, churches, synagogues, and mosques—supporting those who establish **prayer** and **regular charity** [443–444].

Historical accounts of nations like Noah, Aad, and Thamood serve as a warning that Allah reprieves the **unjust** before seizing them. The Messenger is identified as a **plain warner** to humanity, providing good news of **forgiveness** to the believers and a painful return for those who strive against divine revelations.

The text explains that **Satan** interjects his own wishes into the aspirations of every messenger, a process used to test those with **diseased hearts** [444–445]. On the Day of Judgment, absolute **sovereignty** will belong to Allah, who will judge between humanity with the **Truth**.

Generous provisions are promised for those who **emigrate** in the cause of Allah, and the text highlights natural phenomena—such as the merging of night and day—as proofs of **Divine Power**. It establishes that Allah is the only **Reality**, while any other deities invoked are merely **vanity** [445–446].

Every community is assigned **acts of devotion**, and believers are instructed not to let others dispute these matters of guidance. The text highlights Allah's comprehensive knowledge of the **Book** and condemns the worship of that for which no **warrant** was sent down.

sections.theme: The Fly Parable and the Religion of Abraham
sections.summary: A parable featuring a **fly** is used to demonstrate the powerlessness of false gods and those who invoke them. The surah concludes with a command to **strive (Jihad)** for Allah, adhering to the legacy of **Abraham**, who named the believers **Muslims** so they may be witnesses to mankind through **prayer** and **charity**.
